sen.j: 検非違使（けびいし、けんびいし）は日本の律令制下の令外官の一つ。
sen.e: Kebiishi is one of the Ryoge no kans (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
Kebiishi was a Ryoge no kan post (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).
Kebiishi was a Ryoge no kan post (class outside of the Ritsuryo system) under the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the Ritsuryo Code).

sen.j: 「非違を検察する」の意。
sen.e: It means 'doing justice.'
The meaning of the post was to "do justice."
sen.cmt: first translation was too short of a sentence so I lengthened it
sen.e: The meaning of the post was to 'do justice.'
sen.cmt: クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 検非違使庁の官人。
sen.e: Kebiishi is a government official of Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief).
Kebiishi was a government official within the Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief).
Kebiishi was a government official within the Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief).

sen.j: 佐と尉の唐名は廷尉。
sen.e: The Tang name of suke (assistant) and jyo (military officer) are Eni (fourth rank of the Kyukei (nine government posts of Han dynasty)).
The Tang name for the Suke (assistant) and Jyo (military officer) was Eni (Fourth Rank of the Kyukei [Nine government posts of the Han Dynasty]).
sen.cmt: used brackets instead of double parenthesis
sen.e: The Tang name for the Suke (assistant) and Jo (military officer) was Eni (Fourth Rank of the Kyukei (Nine government posts of the Han Dynasty)).

sen.j: 京都の治安維持と民政を所管した。
sen.e: Kebiishi took charge of maintaining security and handling civil affairs in Kyoto.
Kebiishi were in charge of maintaining security and handling civil affairs in Kyoto.
Kebiishi were in charge of maintaining security and handling civil affairs in Kyoto.

sen.j: また、平安時代後期には令制国にも置かれるようになった。
sen.e: To maintain security, it was also placed in ryoseikoku (province) in the late Heian period.
For security purposes, the post was also placed in Ryoseikoku (provinces) in the late Heian Period.
For security purposes, the post was also placed in Ryoseikoku (provinces) in the late Heian period.

sen.j: 平安時代の弘仁7年（816年）が初見で、その頃に設置されたと考えられている。
sen.e: The first appearance of Kebiishi was in 816, the Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is believed that the post of Kebiishi was created during the Heian Period in 816 as this was the first time it appeared.
sen.cmt: combined the following sentence with this one for better flow
sen.e: It is believed that the post of Kebiishi was created during the Heian period in 816 as this was the first time it appeared.
sen.cmt: 原文を1文に戻しました。

sen.j: 当初は衛門府の役人が宣旨によって兼務していた。
sen.e: At first, government official of Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) combined with Kebiishi based on senji (imperial decree).
At first, government officials of Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) combined with Kebiishi based on Senji (Imperial Decree).
At first, government officials of Emonfu (Headquarters of the Outer Palace Guards) combined with Kebiishi based on Senji (Imperial Decree).

sen.j: 官位相当は無い。
sen.e: There is no Kebiishi equivalent to official court rank.
Kebiishi did not have an official court rank.
Kebiishi did not have an official court rank.

sen.j: 五位から昇殿が許され殿上人となるため、武士の出世の目安となっていた。
sen.e: Because a Kebiishi could become a tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) who was allowed into access to the imperial palace when he or she was placed in goi (Fifth Rank), Kebiishi became a measure of success for Samurai.
As a Kebiishi could become a Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) the post became a measure of success for a Samurai when they were placed in goi (Fifth Rank).
sen.cmt: The content in the parenthesis and the content in the sentence say the same thing, so I eliminated one
sen.e: As a Kebiishi could become a Tenjobito (a high-ranking courtier allowed into the Imperial Palace) the post became a measure of success for a samurai when they were placed in goi (Fifth Rank).

sen.j: 司法を担当していた刑部省、警察・監察を担当していた弾正台、都に関わる行政・治安・司法を統括していた京職等の他の官庁の職掌を段々と奪うようになり、検非違使は大きな権力を振るうようになった。
sen.e: Kebiishi took more and more official duties out of other authorities such as Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) responsible for judiciary branch, danjodai (Board of Censors) responsible for police and inspection, Kyoshiki（Capital Bureau）controlling administrative, security, and judiciary branches related to capital, and then exercised enormous power.

Kebiishi took more and more official duties from other authorities such as Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) who was responsible for the judiciary branch, Danjodai (Board of Censors) who was responsible for police and inspections, Kyoshiki (Capital Bureau) who controlled administrative security and other judiciary branches related to the capital, and exercised enormous power.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar and made sure all job titles were capitalized
sen.e: Kebiishi took more and more official duties from other authorities such as Gyobusho (Ministry of Justice) who was responsible for the judiciary branch, Danjodai (Board of Censors) who was responsible for police and inspections, Kyoshiki (Capital Bureau) who controlled administrative security and other judiciary branches related to the capital, and exercised enormous power.

sen.j: 平安時代後期には刑事事件に関する職権行使のために律令とはちがった性質の「庁例」（使庁の流例ともいわれた慣習法）を適用するようになった。
sen.e: In the late Heian period, Cho-Rei (the law enacted by the "Kebiishi") (common law called historical custom of Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief)) different from the Ritsuryo codes was applied in order to exercise its authority on criminal cases.

In the late Heian Period, Cho-Rei (the law enacted by the Kebiishi) (a common law called a historical custom of the Kebiishicho), different from the Ritsuryo Code, was applied in order to exercise the authority of the Kebiishi in criminal cases.

In the late Heian period, 'Cho-Rei' (a common law called a historical custom of the Kebiishicho), different from the Ritsuryo Code, was applied in order to exercise the authority of the Kebiishi in criminal cases.
sen.cmt: 用語補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: また、この頃から検非違使庁における事務は別当の自宅で行われるようになった。
sen.e: Around that time, clerical works for Kebiishicho was done at Betto's place.
Around that time, clerical work for the Kebiishicho were taken care of at the Betto's home.
Around that time, clerical work for the Kebiishicho were taken care of at the residence of Betto (Superintendent).

sen.j: 平安時代末期になると院政の軍事組織である北面武士に取って代わられた。
sen.e: At the end of Heian period, Kebiishis were replaced with Imperial Palace Guards for the north side which were militant organization of Insei (rule by the retired Emperor).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: At the end of the Heian Period, Kebiishi were replaced by Imperial Palace Guards for the North Side, who were a militant organization of Insei (ruled by the retired Emperor).
At the end of the Heian period, Kebiishi were replaced by Imperial Palace Guards for the North Side, who were a militant organization of Insei (ruled by the retired Emperor).

sen.j: 更に鎌倉幕府が六波羅探題を設置すると次第に弱体化した。
sen.e: Furthermore, when the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese federal government headed by shogun) established the Rokuhara Tandai (an administrative and judicial agency in Rokuhara, Kyoto), Kebiishi was gradually weakened.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Furthermore, when the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) established the Rokuhara Tandai (an administrative and judicial agency in Rokuhara, Kyoto), Kebiishi were gradually weakened.
sen.cmt: fixed content in parenthesis pertaining to the Kamakura bakufu since it contained a spelling error and did nto match the word list; fixed grammar
sen.e: Furthermore, when the Kamakura bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) established the Rokuhara Tandai (an administrative and judicial agency in Rokuhara, Kyoto), Kebiishi were gradually weakened.

sen.j: そして、室町時代には幕府が京都に置かれ、侍所に権限を掌握されることになった。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the bakufu was placed in Kyoto, and the power was held by Samurai-dokoro (the Board of Retainers).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: During the Muromachi Period, the bakufu was placed in Kyoto and authority became held by the Samuraidokoro (Board of Retainers).
sen.cmt: fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: During the Muromachi period, the bakufu was placed in Kyoto and authority became held by the Samuraidokoro (Board of Retainers).

tit.cmt: capitalized since this is the title of a section

sen.j: 別当
sen.e: Betto (the superintendent)
Betto (Superintendent)
Betto
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 四等官の長官（カミ）に相当する。
sen.e: It is equivalent to Kami (director) of Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks).
A Betto was equivalent to the Kami (director) of the Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks).
A Betto was equivalent to the Kami (director) of the Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks).

sen.j: 定員は1名で、左右衛門督と左右兵衛督のいずれかを兼ねる中納言・権中納言または参議が務めるのが慣例であった。
sen.e: The number of Bettos was limited to one, and Chunagon (middle counsellor) or Sangi (councillor) who combined either Saemon no kami (Captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Uemon no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) or Sahyoe no kami (Captain of the Left Division of Middle Palace Guards) and Uhyoe no kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards) used to serve as a Betto.

There was only one Betto post and was held by the Chunagon (middle counselor) or the Sangi (counselor) who also held the posts of either Saemon no kami (Captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Uemon no Kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) or Sahyoe no Kami (Captain of the Left Division of Middle Palace Guards) or Uhyoe no Kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: fixed spelling errors; made sure all job titles were capitalized;
sen.e: There was only one Betto post and was held by the Chunagon (vice-councilor of state), Gon Chunagon (a provisional vice-councilor of state) or the Sangi (counselor) who also held the posts of either Saemon no kami (Captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Uemon no Kami (Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) or Sahyoe no Kami (Captain of the Left Division of Middle Palace Guards) or Uhyoe no Kami (Captain of the Right Division of Middle Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 一部補足し、用語集に合わせました。

sen.j: なお、検非違使別当は検非違使を統轄する最高責任者ではあるが、自身は検非違使ではない。
sen.e: Kebiishi no Betto (Superintendent of the Imperial Police) was the highest responsible person of Kebiishi but not Kebiishi.
Kebiishi no Betto (Superintendent of the Imperial Police) held the highest authority of the Kebiishi but was not personally a Kebiishi.
Kebiishi no Betto (Superintendent of the Imperial Police) held the highest authority of the Kebiishi but was not personally a Kebiishi.

sen.j: 佐
sen.e: Suke (assistant)
Suke (assistant)
Suke
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 四等官の次官（スケ）に相当する。
sen.e: It is equivalent to Suke (assistant director) of Shitokan (four classifications of bureaucrats' ranks).
A Suke of the Government Inner Service was a post equivalent to the assistant director (also called Suke) of the Shitokan.
sen.cmt: added details for clarification; fixed grammar; eliminated content in parenthesis pertaining to the Shitokan since it is already described above
sen.e: A Suke of the Government Inner Service was a post equivalent to the assistant director (also called Suke) of the Shitokan.

sen.j: 定員は2名で、左右衛門権佐が兼務していた。
sen.e: The number of Sukes was limited to two, and Uemon Gon no suke (provisional assistant captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Saemon no gon no suke (provisional assistant captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) served as a Suke.

There were only two posts of Suke which were served by the Uemon Gon no Suke (provisional assistant captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Saemon no Gon no Suke (provisional assistant captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards).

There were only two posts of Suke which were served by the Uemon Gon no Suke (provisional assistant captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Saemon no Gon no Suke (provisional assistant captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards).

sen.j: なお、原則として検非違使を務めるのは権官である左右衛門権佐であり、正官である左右衛門佐が検非違使を務めることはない。
sen.e: As a general rule, Uemon Gon no suke and Saemon no gon no suke who were kenkans (powerful post, official) served as a Kebiishi but Saemon no suke (assistant captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Uemon no suke (Assistant Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) who were seikans (regular post, official) had never served as a Kebiishi.

As a general rule, Uemon Gon no Suke and Saemon no Gon no Suke were Kenkan (a powerful offical post) and served as Kebiishi, but the Saemon no Suke (Assistant Captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Uemon no Suke (Assistant Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) were Seikan (a regular official post) and never served as Kebiishi.
sen.cmt: made sure all job titles were capitalized; fixed grammar
sen.e: As a general rule, Uemon Gon no Suke and Saemon no Gon no Suke were Gonkan (a powerful official post) and served as Kebiishi, but the Saemon no Suke (Assistant Captain of the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Uemon no Suke (Assistant Captain of the Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) were Seikan (a regular official post) and never served as Kebiishi.
sen.cmt: 「権官」は律令制では「ごんかん」と読むため修正しました。スペル修正しました。

sen.j: 別当は兼務が多かったので実質的に検非違使庁の責任者であった。
sen.e: Because Betto was often combined with other government post, virtually Suke was the responsible person of Kebiishicho (Office of Police and Judicial Chief).
Suke were essentially the person in charge at a Kebishiicho since Betto were often combined with other governments posts.
sen.cmt: Changed sentence order and fixed grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: Suke were essentially the person in charge at a Kebiishicho since Betto were often combined with other governments posts.

sen.j: 蔵人で検非違使佐を兼ねる蔵人佐や、蔵人・弁官・検非違使佐を兼ねる三事兼帯もいた。
sen.e: There were also a kurodonosuke (assistant official of kurodo) who combined a Kurodo (Chamberlain) with a Kebiishi no suke (assistant official of the Police and Judicial Chief), and a sanji kentai (filling three positions) who combined a Kurodo with a benkan (officials of the dajokan) and a Kebiishi no suke.

There was also a post of Kurodonosuke (assistant official of the Kurodo) who double posted as a Kurodo (Chamberlain) and a Kebiishi no Suke (assistant official of the Police and Judicial Chief), as well as a Sanji Kentai (a post that filled three positions) that held the post of Kurodo, Benkan (official of the Daijokan) and a Kebiishi no suke.
sen.cmt: fixed grammar, capitalization of titles, typos, and grammar to read more naturally
sen.e: There was also a post of Kurodonosuke (assistant official of the Kurodo) who double posted as a Kurodo (Chamberlain) and a Kebiishi no Suke (assistant official of the Police and Judicial Chief), as well as a Sanji Kentai (a post that filled three positions) that held the post of Kurodo, Benkan (official of the Daijokan) and a Kebiishi no suke.

sen.j: 大尉
sen.e: Daijo (Senior Lieutenant)

sen.j: 定員は4名であった。
sen.e: The number of Daijos was limited to four.

The number of Daijo posts was limited to four.

sen.j: そして、衛門大尉が兼務していた。
sen.e: Uemon no Taijo (Senior Lieutenant of Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Saemon no daijo (Senior Lieutenant at the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) combined with Daijo.

sen.e: Uemon no Daijo (Senior Lieutenant of Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Saemon no Daijo (Senior Lieutenant at the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) held the position of Daijo as a second post.
sen.cmt: 兼務→holding two posts concurrently <http://www.csse.monash.edu.au/~jwb/cgi-bin/wwwjdic.cgi?1F>; fixed grammar
sen.e: Uemon no Daijo (Senior Lieutenant of Right Division of Outer Palace Guards) and Saemon no Daijo (Senior Lieutenant at the Left Division of Outer Palace Guards) held the position of Daijo as a second post.

sen.j: 明法家である坂上氏及び中原氏が世襲するようになった。
sen.e: The Sakanoue clan and the Nakahara clan who were lawyers held this post by succession.
The position of Daijo became a hereditary post for the Sakanoue and Nakahara clans as they practiced law.
The position of Daijo became a hereditary post for the Sakanoue and Nakahara clans as Myohoka (teacher of law).

sen.j: 10世紀後半頃から源氏や平氏などの武士がなることが多かった。
sen.e: From the late 10th century, the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan often had this responsibility.
From the late 10th century, the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan often held this post.
From the late 10th century, the Minamoto clan and the Taira clan often held this post.

sen.j: 源義経を九郎判官と呼ぶのもこの官職に就いていたからである。

sen.j: 定員は不定で、若年の明法家がなることが多かった。
sen.e: The number of Shojos was not limited, and young layers often had this responsibility.
There was no limit to the number officers who could old this post.
sen.cmt: Is "Shojos" an error here? Shouldn't it be "Daishi"?

sen.j: 看督長（かどのおさ）
sen.e: Kadonoosa
Kadonoosa
Kadonoosa

sen.j: 罪人を収監する監獄を管理する役であったが、後に罪人を捕縛する役になる。
sen.e: Kadonoosa was responsible for controlling the prison to lock up criminals, and later responsible for capturing criminals.
Kadonoosa was responsible for controlling the prison, locking up criminals, and later responsible for capturing criminals.
Kadonoosa was responsible for controlling the prison, locking up criminals, and later responsible for capturing criminals.

sen.j: 赤狩衣、白衣、布袴に白杖を持つ異形のいでたちで職務に当たった。
sen.e: Kadonoosa performed a duty in his strange outfits, a red Kariginu (robe), a white frock, and hogo (hoko) with a while walking stick in his hand.
Kadonoosa performed their duty in an atypical outfit consisting of a red Kariginu (robe), a white frock, and held a white walking stick.
Kadonoosa performed their duty in an atypical outfit consisting of a red Kariginu (robe), a white frock, and held a white walking stick.

sen.j: 案主（あんじゅ）
sen.e: Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at Shoens, authorities)
Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at a Shoen; manor)
Anju (officer who recorded and stored documents at a Shoen; manor)

Anju was a clerical officer of the Kebiishicho which was initially limited to one post but was later increased.

sen.j: 放免
sen.e: Homen
Homen
Homen

sen.j: 元罪人で、下部とも呼び、罪を許され検非違使庁で働くものである。
sen.e: Homen was a former criminal and also called a Shimobe whose sin was forgiven and worked for Kebiishicho.
Homen was a former criminal, also referred to as a Shimobe, whose sins had been forgiven and worked for the Kebiishicho.
Homen was a former criminal, also referred to as a Shimobe, whose sins had been forgiven and worked for the Kebiishicho.

sen.j: 実際に犯罪者を探索し、捕縛や拷問を担当した。

Homen were in fact put in charge of searching for criminals and responsible for their capture and torture.

sen.j: 備考

Remarks
Remarks

sen.j: 初期のコンピュータゲーム『平安京エイリアン』のプレイヤーズ・キャラクターは検非違使という設定であった。
sen.e: Player's character of early computer game "Heiankyo Alien" was modeled on Kebiishi.
There was a player character from an early computer game called "Heiankyo" that was modeled after Kebiishi.
